results.title: Background for reading: stories of Holland
results.brief_description: Views of Holland are used to provide a background to Dutch literature: views of windmills; canals; dairy farms and farm houses; fishing boats on the Zuyder Zee; old-fashioned costumes worn by the people; the dikes; tulip growing; views of the town of Leiden; Rembrandt’s studio and the old Church of St Peter’s.

results.title: Background for literature: The Lady of the lake
results.brief_description: Scottish scenes are used to illustrate excerpts from Sir Walter Scott’s poem “Lady of the lake”. The film, which includes a brief outline of the author’s life, is intended to demonstrate the concept that literature has its roots in actual places and people.

results.title: Backdrop for a play
results.brief_description: Shows the activities of a group of children who prepare thw backdrop, scenery and costumes and act out the fairy tale “Puss in Boots”, against a background of a deserted colonial mansion in the midlands of Tasmania.

results.title: Backbeat (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: PolyGram, Scala, Channel Four Films, Finola Dwyer, Stephen Woolley and Iain Softley
results.brief_description: When people remember the Beatles, they think of John, Paul, George and Ringo. However in the early days, the Fab Four were five, when Stuart Sutcliffe played alongside the legendary musicians. Sutcliffe (Stephen Dorff) had only a passing interest in music and a passion for painting. For his best friend, John Lennon (Ian Hart), Rock’n’Roll was the only art. “Backbeat” tells the true and tragic story of their friendship, the music, the woman who came between them and the wild times they shared when their innocence was lost. The legend was born.

results.title: Back to work
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
Explores mothers returning to the workforce. Examines issues such as the costs of returning to the workforce, reasons for returning and childcare for preschool and school age children.

results.title: Back to the past: Westbourne Grammar School
results.brief_description:
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.
Features Charles “Bud” Tingwell

results.title: Back to the past (April 2006)
results.brief_description:
“Back to the Past” is a program for primary schools to learn scripting, production and performance skills using virtual set technology. Starring Charles “Bud Tingwell ” as a time travelling scientist, BTTP sends students back in time to historical Melbourne using archival footage, animation and green screen technology.
Back to the Past or “Screening Melbourne” is designed to encourage students to develop an appreciation for the art and the craft behind moving image in its many forms by developing their ability to think beyond the screen. In the program Students become actors in a sci-fi time travel film story during a blue-screen workshop that allows them to place themselves in a historical Melbourne setting, engage with a screening program featuring historical Melbourne footage and participate in a related discussion
learn some simple editing skills while they create a digital ‘Melbourne travelogue’
Back to the Past aims to develop students’ understanding of ways in which film-makers create screen texts to target particular audiences. Students in Years 3-4 learn about concepts related to camera use such as framing, shot types, and angles as well as some of the features of documentary and blue-screen technology.

results.title: Back to the future
results.creator_credit: Amblin Entertainment, Bob Gale, Neil Canton and Robert Zemeckis
results.brief_description: Marty McFly (Michael J Fox) and Doc (Christopher Lloyd) have to save the present by going back to the future in this classic from the 1980s.

constellations_other.name: Obviously the time continuum has been disrupted...again and again and again!
constellations_other.description: Eadweard Muybridge was able to capture time and play it back again creating endless time paradoxes where subjects are destined to repeat their previous actions. Filmmakers have since explored such notions via time travel narratives questioning destiny, fate and choice.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Amblin Entertainment, Bob Gale, Neil Canton and Robert Zemeckis
results.description: Michael J. Fox stars as Marty McFly, transported by his friend Doc’s time machine to 1955. Marty rubs shoulders with a much younger version of his parents and sees a side to them he never knew existed. The only problem is that the car responsible for sending him back to 1955 has run out of the plutonium required to fuel the car. Marty must convince Doc that his idea for a time machine, conceived in 1955 was a reality in the 1980s. As a further complication, Marty must ensure his parents-to-be meet and fall in love.
description_for_label: Michael J. Fox stars as Marty McFly, transported by his friend Doc’s time machine to 1955.
